items.synopsis: Children have suffered multiple traumatic injuries, including amputations and crushed limbs, after a school bus was struck from behind by a truck in Melbourne's outer-west yesterday. The truck driver has been charged.

title.children: Charges laid after horror bus crash that left children with amputations, spinal injuries

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit with glasses speaks behind a microphone-laden lectern in front of the Sydney Opera House.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese cancels a major meeting of the leaders of the United States, India, Japan and Australia that was set to be hosted at the Sydney Opera House, after US President Joe Biden cancels his visit.

title.children: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese cancels Quad meeting after US President Joe Biden pulls out

image.altText: A worker inspects solar panels at a solar farm in China.

items.synopsis: For millions of Australians, solar panels have been a ticket to cheap, clean power. But researchers and human rights activists warn there's a dark side to their supply and changes are needed.

title.children: 'Dark underbelly': The hidden human toll behind Australia's love affair with cheap solar panels

image.altText: Joe Biden in sunglasses speaking while Anthony Albanese looks on

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese might be disappointed that he won't get to host his Sydney summit, but he knows that Australia would also pay if America defaults on its debts, writes Carrington Clarke.

title.children: The US plunges into debt crisis regularly — this time Biden was nervous enough to bail on Albanese

image.altText: A group of men walk along a street in front of the US Capitol on a stormy day.

items.synopsis: The United States is rapidly running out of money to pay its bills unless the Republicans and Democrats can agree on a new deal. Here's how the US got here, and what it means for Australia.

title.children: 'It's a really huge deal': Why the US debt ceiling crisis has implications for Australia

image.altText: A kitchen worker prepares food at the Golden Sheath Hotel

items.synopsis: The official Wage Price Index from the Bureau of Statistics shows pay packets lifted 0.8 per cent in the March quarter and 3.7 per cent over the year to March.

title.children: Wages growth close to forecasts takes pressure off RBA for further rate rises

image.altText: A man with grey hair with a fireman's hat behind him

items.synopsis: Despite being gradually phased out, the toxic chemicals are still found in products like household cookware, waterproof jackets, stain resistant carpets and food packaging, experts say.

title.children: 'It's in everyone's blood': Australian government urged to ban PFAS chemicals amid health concerns

image.altText: Three firefighters stand outside in the dark in Wellington with one being sprayed with sprinklers

items.synopsis: A devastating fire ravaged through a hostel in New Zealand's capital early Tuesday morning, taking the lives of at least six people. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: What we know about the Loafers Lodge hostel fire

image.altText: Israel Folau points to the sky with both hands and looks up in a blue rugby shirt

items.synopsis: His contributions to rugby league and union are beyond reproach, however, his sacking from the Wallabies after expressing his religious beliefs sparked a debate that continues to polarise to this day.

title.children: 'That's what made us angry': Wallabies teammate opens up about the Israel Folau saga

image.altText: Composite image of a young woman at laptop, older man at cafe

items.synopsis: Younger Australians are being forced to change their behaviour to deal with the rising cost of living, a report based on the financial data of 7 million people shows.

title.children: If demand is causing Australia's inflation crisis, new data shows which age groups are behind it

image.altText: A man with short salt and pepper coloured hair and slight beard stands in front of a stone wall

items.synopsis: While New Zealanders have welcomed easier, cheaper pathways to gain Australian citizenship, some say they were left in the dark about plans to abolish an expensive visa that will soon be redundant.

title.children: Rob paid $4,000 for a visa that will soon be 'redundant' — and he's not the only one

image.altText: The tail of a Jetstar aircraft showing its name an livery

items.synopsis: Jetstar travellers will need to arrive at the airport earlier, after the carrier announced a series of changes it hopes to "boost punctuality and reliability".

title.children: Jetstar's new changes mean travellers will need to arrive earlier for check-in and boarding

image.altText: woman in pink dress and sunglasses with crossed hands

items.synopsis: Somali-Australian designer Asia Hassan has debuted the first modest fashion runway at Australian Fashion Week.

title.children: Australian Fashion Week captures rise of growing modesty movement in colourful runway first

image.altText: Three female models outdoors wearing white lines skirts and tops, featuring Indigenous-themed designs.

items.synopsis: Stolen Generations survivor Lauren Jarrett and her daughter Melissa Greenwood have travelled from their regional hometown to Sydney to showcase their unique fashion creations and their culture.

title.children: 'It's quite surreal': Stolen Generations survivor, daughter debut designs at Australian Fashion Week

image.altText: A yellow Ray White sign that says "lease" in front of a freestanding home.

items.synopsis: There are at least four things that would do more to restrain rents than Labor’s $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund – and one of them would do it a lot quicker, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Restrict negative gearing — and three other ways to bring down rent and build houses faster than Labor's $10b fund

image.altText: A close up of Angus speaking against a dark blue background.

items.synopsis: Angus Taylor addresses the National Press Club for his post-budget address, one week after Treasurer Jim Chalmers handed down his second budget.

title.children: Shadow treasurer delivers post-budget address at National Press Club — as it happened

image.altText: A bald shirtless man faces a white wall, his back is covered in elaborate tattoos

items.synopsis: Harusan felt he had little choice in life but to follow his father's footsteps and become a Japanese gangster. It was a path that landed him in jail for years, but now, he is ready to fight Russian invaders on the front line in Ukraine.

title.children: Harusan had no military experience or Ukrainian language skills. This foreign fighting unit took him on anyway

image.altText: A man with a grey beard wearing glasses with one dark lens and one clear one.

items.synopsis: Novelist Salman Rushdie has warned that countries in the West face the most-severe threats to freedom of expression and freedom to publish in his lifetime, speaking nine months after a man repeatedly stabbed him while he was on stage in New York.

title.children: Salman Rushdie says freedom of expression under attack, nine months after being stabbed on stage

image.altText: Tinder app

items.synopsis: A West Australian man is charged with 64 offences relating to the alleged rape and sexual assault of nine women he met on online dating apps, with police saying they have identified more potential victims.

title.children: Alleged serial dating app rapist had hundreds of thousands of images on his phone, police say

image.altText: A blonde woman shows her bare back as she sketches a nude model. The nude model is standing on a stage.

items.synopsis: At a former strip club in Kings Cross, Magnolia's Art Class encourages participants to drop their robes and take out their sketch pads.

title.children: 'Say hello to my new body': Malaika finds courage to get naked in front of strangers at drawing class

image.altText: An 18th century sandstone home with white trimmings

items.synopsis: The historic former homestead of renowned artist Arthur Boyd was gifted to the Australian public in the 1990s and has operated as a national museum since.

title.children: This 19th century sandstone homestead once owned by artist Arthur Boyd has been restored to its former glory

image.altText: The front cover of Mem Fox's 1988 children's picture book 'Guess What?'

items.synopsis: Education authorities in the US county of Duval, in Florida, reject claims a book by renowned Australian children's author Mem Fox has been banned from classrooms, saying the work has instead been "approved" for school libraries and is not on a list of 21 "not-approved" titles.

title.children: Mem Fox book not banned but 'approved' for school libraries, US county says

image.altText: A woman in a blue short holding a photograph of a young Aboriginal man

items.synopsis: Glenys's son died by suicide, and now her grandson is threatening self-harm. With suicide rates rising after the pandemic, what are we doing to prevent this tragic loss of life?

title.children: 'Nan can you take me to hospital?': Suicide rates rising across Australia as pandemic effects take toll

image.altText: A hippo yawning at a lake in Kenya.

items.synopsis: A child has died and 23 people are missing after a hippo capsized a canoe in Malawi, Africa.

title.children: Hippo capsizes canoe, killing one and leaving 23 missing in river in Malawi, Africa

image.altText: A wooden carving depicting a woman

items.synopsis: Art Gallery of New South Wales has returned an 800-year-old wooden carving to the Nepalese temple it was taken from, but after 20 years of work, and with so many more stolen pieces in their collection, experts say more needs to be done.

title.children: Sydney gallery returns stolen Nepalese carving, despite knowing for 20 years it was stolen

image.altText: An aerial photo of loch ard gorge

items.synopsis: Authorities have closed access to one of the Great Ocean Road's most popular tourist attractions, the beach steps at Loch Ard Gorge, amid fears of a cliff collapse.

title.children: Fears of fatal cliff face collapse force authorities to close popular Great Ocean Road attraction

image.altText: French president and French first lay looking out to the rights side of the photo's framing.

items.synopsis: The great-nephew of French first lady was attacked on the sidelines of a demonstration against her husband Emmanuel Macron's retirement age reforms.

title.children: French first lady's relative assaulted during demonstration over pension reforms

image.altText: A Bushmaster sporting Ukrainian flags stands in front of a Globemaster airplane on the tarmac

items.synopsis: Bendigo-based Thales Australia signs a contract to build another order of 78 troop-carrying and command vehicles for the Australian Army.

title.children: Australia commits $160m to build more Bushmasters after donating 90 to Ukraine in war against Russia

image.altText: An F1 driver wearing his racing suit, no helmet, looks on in the garage while holding his ear.

items.synopsis: McLaren has a total of 14 points from the opening five races of the season, as they are locked in a battle for fifth place in the constructors' championship.

title.children: Oscar Piastri takes 'many learnings' from Miami F1 disaster

image.altText: a husband and wife stand arm-in-arm with bleak expressions in front of an unfinished home

items.synopsis: Mali wanted to achieve the "great Australian dream" of owning her own home. It turned into a nightmare when one of the country's largest builders collapsed.

title.children: 'Unbelievably hard': Families left in limbo after collapse of Porter Davis

image.altText: A group of people in white t-shirt gowns hold signs up with "Iran, your death penalty makes us sick"

items.synopsis: An Amnesty International report has revealed the number of executions around the world increased by 53 per cent in 2022.

title.children: Executions increase worldwide by 53pc, Amnesty International report says

image.altText: A man in blue suit sitting at desk with people sitting behind him. He has a straight face.

items.synopsis: US Congress hears from the head of the artificial intelligence company that makes ChatGPT that the use of artificial intelligence to interfere with election integrity is a "significant area of concern", adding that it needs regulation.

title.children: 'I am nervous about it': Head of AI company that makes ChatGPT testifies at US Congress

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Australian share market has opened lower as Incitec Pivot records a lower profit result, after the US Treasury secretary warns a recession is likely unless a deal is struck over the debt ceiling. Follow live.

title.children: ASX opens lower as Incitec Pivot's profit falls, US recession warning as debt ceiling deadline looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The official Wage Price Index from the Bureau of Statistics shows pay packets lifted 0.8% in the March quarter and 3.7% over the year to March. Economists had generally expected wages to lift 0.9 per cent in the quarter and 3.6 per cent over the year. The wage data is a key economic indicator used by the Reserve Bank ahead of its interest rate decision next month.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pay packets have increased slightly, ABS wage data shows

children.content: The official Wage Price Index from the Bureau of Statistics shows pay packets lifted 0.8% in the March quarter and 3.7% over the year to March.
Economists had generally expected wages to lift 0.9 per cent in the quarter and 3.6 per cent over the year.
The wage data is a key economic indicator used by the Reserve Bank ahead of its interest rate decision next month.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected, the Australian share market has followed in Wall Street's footsteps and opened lower. It's down -0.9% as of 10:45am, with all sectors in the red (with the exception of technology and utilities). Incitec Pivot has shed the most value so far this morning, thanks to posting lower profit of $353.6 million Its profit is down 7.9% compared to this time last year. The top movers so far (although they are subdued) in the early half include: Life360 +2.16% Xero +1.7% REA Group +1.5% Virgin Money UK +1.45 James Hardie Industries +1.4% At the other end, the losses are a tad more dramatic: Incitec Pivot -6.1% Paladin Energy -3.8% Sayona Mining -3.3% Perseus Mining -3.1% Regis Resources -2.8%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower as Incitec Pivot falls after posting lower profit

children.content: As expected, the Australian share market has followed in Wall Street's footsteps and opened lower.
It's down -0.9% as of 10:45am, with all sectors in the red (with the exception of technology and utilities).
Incitec Pivot has shed the most value so far this morning, thanks to posting lower profit of $353.6 million
Its profit is down 7.9%
compared to this time last year.
The top movers so far (although they are subdued) in the early half include:
Xero +1.7%
REA Group +1.5%
Virgin Money UK +1.45
James Hardie Industries +1.4%
At the other end, the losses are a tad more dramatic:
Incitec Pivot -6.1%
Paladin Energy -3.8%
Sayona Mining -3.3%
Perseus Mining -3.1%
Regis Resources -2.8%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Bureau of Statistics is releasing the Wage Price Index (WPI) at 11:30am AEST. What is it? Put simply, it's a measure of how workers' base pay is changing, and excludes the effect of boosts like bonuses, overtime, hours worked, promotions or shifting jobs/employers. It's the change in how much people are getting paid per hour for doing the same job for the same employer, and thus pretty much akin to the inflation rate for wages. It's important for the RBA for two reasons. The first is that higher pay rises mean households have more money to spend, which means more demand and that generally keeps consumer price inflation higher — businesses have no reason to cut prices if people are still buying their goods or services. The second is that wages are a large input cost for most businesses, the largest for many. This is especially so in the services sector, where the most recent inflation figures showed an acceleration in price rises. If wages rise too fast, the RBA is concerned businesses will pass through those increased costs, sending inflation higher still. The good news (or bad news if you desperately need a pay rise to keep up with your mortgage/rent/grocery bills) is that there's been few signs of wages across the board rising particularly fast. The economist forecasts for today's WPI centre on pay rises of 0.9% over the March quarter and 3.6% over the past year, up from 0.8% and 3.3% in the December quarter reading. Given that consumer price inflation was 7% over the March quarter, workers are still expected to be taking a big real pay cut, but at least they're not contributing much to inflation in Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wages data the key focus today

featuredLink.title: Profits haven't contributed to inflation? Former treasury economist says it's not that simple

children.content: The
Australian Bureau of Statistics
is releasing the
Wage Price Index (WPI)
at 11:30am AEST.
What is it?
Put simply, it's a measure of how workers' base pay is changing, and excludes the effect of boosts like bonuses, overtime, hours worked, promotions or shifting jobs/employers.
It's the change in how much people are getting paid per hour for doing the same job for the same employer
, and thus pretty much akin to the inflation rate for wages.

It's important for the RBA for two reasons. The first is that higher pay rises mean households have more money to spend, which means more demand and that generally keeps consumer price inflation higher — businesses have no reason to cut prices if people are still buying their goods or services.
The second is that wages are a large input cost for most businesses, the largest for many.
This is especially so in the services sector, where
the most recent inflation figures showed an acceleration in price rises
If wages rise too fast, the RBA is concerned businesses will pass through those increased costs, sending inflation higher still.
The good news (or bad news if you desperately need a pay rise to keep up with your mortgage/rent/grocery bills) is that there's been few signs of wages across the board rising particularly fast.
The economist forecasts for today's WPI centre on pay rises of 0.9% over the March quarter and 3.6% over the past year
, up from 0.8% and 3.3% in the December quarter reading.
Given that consumer price inflation was 7% over the March quarter, workers are still expected to be taking a big real pay cut, but at least they're not contributing much to inflation in Australia.

image.altText: Researchers have found that here are more than 12,000 dugongs in the Kimberley.

items.synopsis: Locals are urged to take extra care on the water as a dugong — usually found further north — makes a rare visit to the Tweed River's seagrass meadows.

title.children: Warning for boaties as 'displaced' Dugong makes new home in Tweed River
